perturbation.original_text: Intellectual Property rights in an unelected country shall revert to Marv.
perturbation.changed_text: Intellectual Property rights in an unelected country may revert to Marv, contingent upon Marv's discretion.
perturbation.explanation: The original text clearly states that intellectual property rights *shall* revert. The modified text introduces ambiguity and gives Marv discretionary power, contradicting the original obligation. This can create disputes over the automatic transfer of rights.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Patent Act - 35 U.S. Code § 261 - Ownership; assignment
perturbation.law_explanation: This modification introduces ambiguity around the transfer of patent rights. According to 35 U.S.C. § 261, patent rights are assignable in law by a written instrument. Making the reversion of rights contingent upon discretion undermines the clear assignment required by the statute.
perturbation.scraped_snippet_1: 35 U.S. Code § 261 - Ownership; assignment | U.S. Code | US Law | LII / Legal Information Institute Please help us improve our site! × No thank you Quick search by citation: Title Section Go! 35 U.S. Code § 261 - Ownership; assignment U.S. Code Notes prev | next Subject to the provisions of this title, patents shall have the attributes of personal property. The Patent and Trademark Office shall maintain a register of interests in patents and applications for patents and shall record any document related thereto upon request, and may require a fee therefor. Applications for patent, patents, or any interest therein, shall be assignable in law by an instrument in writing. The applicant, patentee, or his assigns or legal representatives may in like manner grant and convey an exclusive right under his application for patent, or patents, to the whole or any specified part of the United States. A certificate of acknowledgment under the hand and official seal of a person authorized to administer oaths within the United States, or, in a foreign country, of a diplomatic or consular officer of the United States or an officer authorized to administer oaths whose authority is proved by a certificate of a diplomatic or consular officer of the United States, or apostille of an official designated by a foreign country which, by treaty or convention, accords like effect to apostilles of designated officials in the United States, shall be prima facie evidence of the execution of an assignment, grant or conveyance of a patent or application for patent. An interest that constitutes an assignment, grant or conveyance shall be void as against any subsequent purchaser or mortgagee for a valuable consideration, without notice, unless it is recorded in the Patent and Trademark Office within three months from its date or prior to the date of such subsequent purchase or mortgage. (July 19, 1952, ch. 950, 66 Stat. 810 ; Pub. L. 93–596, § 1 , Jan. 2, 1975 , 88 Stat. 1949 ; Pub. L. 97–247, § 14(b) , Aug. 27, 1982

perturbation.original_text: Confidential information shall also mean any information not generally made available or known to the public and shall include, without limitation, all ideas, inventions, software, documentation, flowcharts, diagrams, improvements, discoveries, research and development, know how, formulas, compositions, manufacturing and production processes and techniques, technical data, designs, drawings, plans, specifications, and all other information or material within the definition of a "trade secret" as set forth in the Uniform Trade Secret Act, or which either party otherwise reasonably considers proprietary.
perturbation.changed_text: Confidential information shall also mean any information not generally made available or known to the public and shall include, with limitation, a few ideas, some inventions, certain software, limited documentation, some flowcharts, some diagrams, a few improvements, possible discoveries, possible research and development, a little know how, formulas, compositions, manufacturing and production processes and techniques, technical data, designs, drawings, plans, specifications, and all other information or material within the definition of a "trade secret" as set forth in the Uniform Trade Secret Act, or which either party otherwise reasonably considers proprietary.
perturbation.explanation: By adding limiting words such as 'a few', 'some', 'certain' and 'possible' the scope of Confidential Information is restricted. This contradicts the intention of protecting a wide range of information as trade secrets and could make it difficult to enforce confidentiality obligations.
perturbation.law_explanation: The UTSA defines a trade secret broadly. Section 1(4) defines a trade secret as information that derives independent economic value from not being generally known or readily ascertainable. By limiting the scope of 'confidential information', the modified text potentially excludes information that would otherwise qualify as a trade secret under UTSA, making it harder to protect it. The added words creates uncertainty and hinders the full protection intended by the Act.

perturbation.original_text: Overdue payments hereunder shall be subject to a late payment charge calculated at an annual rate of three percent (3%) over the prime rate or successive prime rates (as posted in New York City) during delinquency. If the amount of such charge exceeds the maximum permitted by law, such charge shall be reduced to such maximum.
perturbation.changed_text: Overdue payments hereunder shall be subject to a late payment charge at the institution's discretion. If the amount of such charge exceeds the maximum desired by the lending institution, such charge shall be determined based on market rates.
perturbation.explanation: The original text sets a clear calculation for late payment charges based on a defined prime rate, capped by the legal maximum. The modified text makes late payment charges discretionary, contradicting the initial fixed calculation and introducing ambiguity. The late charge is to be determined by market rates, which is arbitrary.
perturbation.law_explanation: Pennsylvania's Usury Law (41 P.S. § 201) sets limits on interest rates and late fees. By making the late payment charge discretionary and determined by a 'lending institution', this modification contradicts the statute, as it allows for potential charging of rates beyond the legal limit without a clear, defined calculation method. The institution could set late payment charge beyond the amount that is legally allowed.
